page.title: 01INTRODUCTION
page.content: Okehampton stands on the confluence of the East and West Ockment Rivers, where they leave the northern slopes of Dartmoor. Both the rivers are crossed by the A30 trunk road which passes through the town on route from the East to Cornwall. The town is at the centre of a predominantly pastoral farming area, although its market closed down several years ago. South of the town the land quickly climbs to the Dartmoor National Park. Just to the South West of the stands the Castle, built a few years after 1066. The town is a centre for shopping, employment and education. Although some new industries are being set up, unemployment is higher than the national average, many young people being without proper jobs. The biggest local issue is the route of the proposed Okehampton By-pass.
